question10b.value:
The children sat across from the experimenter. The study consisted of two tasks which were counterbalanced. One task tested children’s preference to learn about novel people categories. The other task tested the children’s tendency to generalize individual information to larger groups.
Preference to Learn. At the beginning of each session, the experimenter familiarized the child with the current setting of Canada, and then introduced to the novel people groups living in different countries in the world, consisting of various skin colors (e.g., People in Zoovia have purple skin). Following this, the experimenter will continue:
Now, I have some facts that I can tell you, but I can only tell you some of them because we don’t have much time. So, I am going to pick up two facts at a time and you will choose the one that you would like to learn the most. Then, I will tell you the facts you chose at the end. Does that make sense? [wait for confirmation] Okay, and remember, we’re imagining that these people are from different countries and the people in each country have a different skin color!
We used 16 cards, each with a drawing of a door on one side and a drawing of a person on the other. The two cards were placed in front of the child on a stand with the door-side facing the child and the person-side facing the experimenter. Therefore, there were eight trials where children were asked which fact they would like to learn and were encouraged to point to the card.  Each child was first be prompted with “Now let’s imagine that we are going on vacation to the country Zoovia. Which fact would you like to learn the most?” One fact is always about the individual person (e.g., “What this person in the picture likes to eat? This Zoovian?) and the other fact is always about the category of person (e.g., “What this category of people like to eat? The Zoovians?; see Table 1 for a complete list of novel names). The order of the singular noun versus plural noun is counterbalanced. 
Tendency to Generalize. In this task, children were shown a dot scale denoting “All”, “Lots”, “Some”, and “Few”. The children were taught what the scale represented and how to use it. The next part of the task introduced children to real pictures of people who were the same gender as a child but were either African-American or Asian depending on the child’s race. If the child was non-Black then we would first present them with an African-American face and ask the child “does this person belong to the same group as you?”. If they answered “yes”, then the experiment continues with the African-American faces. If they answered “no”, then the child is shown an Asian face and asked again, “does this person belong to the same group as you?”. If the child was Black then they were shown a picture of an Asian face and asked “does this person belong to the same group as you?”. The purpose of not including Caucasian faces was to ensure that children were always asked to generalize about an outgroup. This is important because outgroups are seen as more homogenous while outgroups are seen as more heterogenous (Park & Judd, 1990; Quattrone & Jones, 1980). Therefore, we would suspect systemically lower generalization scores for ingroups than outgroups. There were eight different faces for each race. While asking them a question, the picture of the face was held up to them. The questions asked were about novel games, dances, puzzles, and sports (e.g., “This person is really good at a game called gorp. Now thinking about the people from the same country as this person, how many of those people are good at the game called gorp? All, Lots, Some, or Few?”). There were two novel questions for each category (e.g., games, dance, puzzles, and sports) for a total of eight questions. The order of the questions was counterbalanced. At the end of the experiment, the experimenter would read the facts to the child from the preference to learn section, and then the child would be given a prize.

question4b.value: Children ages 9-10 as this is the age children begin to show a preference to learn about categories over individuals.

question5b.value: The data will be collected by several research assistants in various places including the laboratory, school camps, parks, and science centres.

question6b.value: 40 Participants - This is a similar number of participants used in similar studies (see Cimpian & Park, 2013), as well as the predict G*power of an effect size of 0.42, alpha of 0.05 and Power of 0.8.

question7b.value: Data collection ends when the desired number of participants (40), is reached, not including excluded data.

question8b.value: Experimenter error (e.g., pointing to or giving the wrong information to the child)

question9b.value:
If the child is highly distressed: End immediately
If child is not distressed: Tell the child how many questions are left and if they still wish to end the experiment, then end. 
If the child continues after telling the child how many questions are left, then asks again to end the experiment, remind them of how many questions are left, and if they wish to still end it, then end the experiment.

question7c.value: Imputation by taking the mean of all available answers. (e.g., using the average of 7 answers instead of 8)

question10c.value: Due to the limited range, the distribution should be normal and therefore the scores would not need to be corrected. However, if normality is violated then the data would be transformed.

question1a.value: As a child's preference to learn increases, their tendency to generalize increases

question3a.value: No manipulation check was included because no manipulation was conducted.

question5a.value: Previous research has shown that 4+ year-old children and adults have a preference to learn about animal categories, however, it is not until the age of 9 that children begin to show a preference to learn about human categories (Cimpian & Park, 2014; Sutherland & Rule, under review).  At around a similar age of 9 to 10 years old, children begin to believe that race is more stable than emotions (Roberts & Gelman, 2016). Furthermore, children may categorize more if they see race as a good predictor of behavior, and the more they categorize, the more they will start to form beliefs about each category—namely, stereotypes (Pauker, Xu, Williams & Biddle, 2016). Therefore, we sought to address the question of does a child’s preference to learn about categories influence their tendency to generalize traits from individuals to groups.

question1c.value:
Preference to Learn Score: Ask the child if they would rather learn information about and individual (1) or a Group/Kind (0) and taking the average
Tendency to Generalize Score: Ask the child how many of the people from the same country as the person shown (in a picture), are good a the particular sport/game/dance/puzzle, All (3), Lots (2), Some (1), or Few (0) and taking the average

question3c.value:
Preference to Learn - DV
Tendency to Generalize - DV
Gender - Covariate
Child's Race - Covariate
Experimenter's Race - Covariate
Data Sheet - Covariate

question4c.value:
Gender - There may be difference in gender when it comes to generalizing as there has not been gender effects for preference to learn (Sutherland & Rule, under review)
Child's Race - Race effects for stereotyping has been observed in other research (see Pauker, Xu, Williams & Biddle, 2016)
Experimenter's Race - There may be experimenter race effects in which children change their answers depending on the experimenter's race
Data Sheet - There may be order effects of the 4 datasheets in which there are differences in the order of the tasks and the order of the questions.

Data collection ends when the desired number of participants (40), is reached, not including excluded data.

attributes.title: Templated from HUMANISTIC APPROACH TO PRINCIPAL’S LEADERSHIP  AND ITS IMPACTS IN CHARACTER EDUCATION STRENGTHENING
attributes.description: Dear readers  Let me join this scientific group. I am a doctoral student in an education management study program. Currently, I am completing a dissertation. The article that I sent to be read by interested people aims to explore the role of educational leadership in implementing programs to strengthen character education in Indonesia. At present the Indonesian Ministry of Education assigns all schools from the level of early childhood education, elementary school, junior high school, and senior high school to intensify character education in schools. Based on research findings, schools in Indonesia have not yet implemented this program to the fullest. Weaknesses that occur because the principal has not found the suitability of the role with the character education program. Related to this weakness, we conducted research in two schools that have successfully implemented programs to strengthen character education. The success of these two schools lies in the humanistic approach adopted by the principal. Therefore, with all due respect, I invite the reader to know the results of our research, especially with regard to the reasons behind the two principals using the humanistic approach, and how the principal's strategic steps in applying the humanistic approach. Hopefully, I hope this article will give readers new insights into understanding the humanistic approach that is applied in the field of educational leadership

question.value:
This research uses a qualitative approach, analytic descriptive method (Miles, Huberman, & Saldaña, 2014). Through this approach, an actual picture will be observed and analyzed about the reasons underlying the principal using the humanistic approach, and the steps of the principal's humanistic approach. The characteristics of this study are the natural setting as a source of direct data and researchers become a key instrument (Bogdan & Biklen, 1998). As a key instrument, the researcher acts, with the help of others, collecting data through interviews with teachers, staff, students, school committees, parents and students themselves as informants who are actively involved in supporting humanistic approaches.
Sampling using purposive sampling, using the chimney technique. The data collection process starts from extensive data collection related to the overall picture of the principal's humanistic approach, then narrowed to the reasons underlying the principal to use a humanistic approach, and the concrete steps of the principal's humanistic approach in optimizing character education strengthening programs, and how their impact on strengthening student character. This research uses a period of one year, from 2018 to 2019, and is carried out in two schools in Malang, East Java, Indonesia, namely Santa Maria II Catholic Middle School and Sang Timur Catholic Middle School.

q11.value:
The technique used in data analysis was working with data through the process of systematically searching and organizing interview characters, field notes, and other materials collected by the researchers (Creswell, 2009; Miles et al., 2014). The analysis was continued by analyzing data, arranging, dividing into units, synthesizing, looking for patterns, finding what was meaningful and what was examined and reported systematically. At this stage, data analysis was performed and used in such a way as to obtain the truth of the data to answer the research focus. The inductive method was used to manage the qualitative data. The inductive method allowed the arrangement of data in the form of data condensation through the process of selecting, focusing, simplifying, abstracting, and changing the data appearing in comprehensive research from written field notes, interview transcripts, and documents. Then, the data was presented, allowing conclusions and actions making. Temporary conclusions based on matrices had been made to find patterns, topics or themes in accordance with the research focus. 
Checking the Validity of Data
In this research, data was validated using several measures, including first, a measure of credibility (level of trust). The purpose of data credibility is to prove the data suitability with the facts in the research. To establish the validity of the data, the researchers used the following inspection techniques: 1) extending involvement, thus allowing an increased level of confidence in the data collected. By extending involvement, obtain accurate information and subject trust. Therefore, the researchers expanded participation explained in the research background. 2) Perseverance in observation means that researchers in detail looked for and found characteristics and elements in situations that were highly relevant to the problem under the study. 3) Triangulation facilitated data checking by comparing it with something else. This was performed in several stages, including (a) source triangulation, performed by means of: (1) comparing observation data with interview data; (2) comparing what was said in public with what was said privately; (3) comparing what people say about the research situation with what they say all the time; (4) comparing one's circumstances and perspectives with other people's views; (5) comparing the results of interviews with the contents of related documents. (b) Triangulation method by checking the level of confidence in the research findings based on several data sources with the same method. (c) Triangulation theory compared facts with one or more theories as a comparative explanation. 4) Peer examination through discussion with peers. 5) Analysis of negative cases by collecting examples beyond the patterns and trends of information collected and used as a comparison. 6) Examining members, to check whether the data recorded and interpreted by the researchers was appropriate, and the key informants recognized the truth. Second, performing transferability through detailed research reports that referred to the focus of the research. Third, dependability was performed to check or evaluate the accuracy of researchers in conceptualizing data constantly. Fourth, confirmability was performed through test to assess the research results, mainly related to the description of research findings and discussion  (Miles et al., 2014; Yin, 2017).

attributes.title: Linguistic form, causal explanations, and social essentialism
attributes.description: The current study will examine the effect of language and explanation on the development of children and adults’ essentialist beliefs about novel social categories. In particular, we will investigate the joint effects of generic vs. specific language about a category, and biological vs. social explanations of category properties on various indices of social cognition. This project intends to follow up on recent research by Noyes & Keil (2019) that corroborates the effect of generic language on essentialist beliefs (whereby generic language increases essentialism; see Rhodes, Leslie, & Tworek, 2012 and Leshin, Leslie, & Rhodes, under review), but found that it does so only for biological properties. Here, we aim to clarify the relationship between generic language and essentialist beliefs by explicitly manipulating both the language (generic vs. specific) as well as the causal explanations (biological vs. social) provided for different properties. Additionally, since Noyes & Keil (2019)’s project only included adults, we hope to illuminate the developmental trajectory of this phenomenon by including children in our study as well. In these ways, our research aims to elucidate the boundary conditions of the effects of generic language on social essentialism.

q1.value: Josie Benitez, Rachel Leshin, Marjorie Rhodes

q2.value:
The aim of this research is to examine the effects of linguistic form and causal explanations on essentialist beliefs, and explore how these beliefs may shift across age. Some potential data patterns and their interpretations are discussed below:
If language form matters regardless of the causal explanation provided, we should find higher endorsement of essentialism in the generic conditions than the specific conditions (across both explanation conditions). If causal explanation matters regardless of the language form used, we should find higher endorsement of essentialism in the biological origin conditions than the social origin conditions (across both linguistic form conditions). However, if linguistic form elicits essentialist beliefs only when biological explanations are provided, then we should find an interaction between linguistic form and causal explanation such that participants should exhibit higher endorsement of essentialism in the generic-biological condition than any other condition. Comparisons between a sample of children (ages 4.5-7.99) and adults will allow us to characterize how the mechanisms that elicit essentialist beliefs might shift across age. For instance, one possibility is that children exhibit stronger effects of linguistic form (with less differentiation by explanation type) and the interaction between language and explanation strengthens with age.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants will be invited to take part in an online study to assess the effects of language and causal explanations on essentialist beliefs. Subjects will first be shown a storybook that describes 16 properties about a novel group named “Zarpies”. Using a 2x2, fully crossed between-subjects design, participants will be assigned to one of four experimental conditions. Each condition pertains to the form and content of the storybook prompts read aloud to each participant: the prompts vary both in the language form (generic vs. specific) as well as the causal origin (biological vs. social) of the observed Zarpie properties. Thus, participants will hear one of the following: (1) generic prompts paired with biological explanations, (2) generic prompts paired with social explanations, (3) specific prompts paired with biological explanations, or (4) specific prompts paired with social explanations. The storybook, read aloud only once, will be the only exposure that participants will have to the language and explanation manipulations. We will then administer a series of measures that assess distinct dimensions of participants’ essentialist beliefs about Zarpies, including perceptions of (a) category-based explanations for properties, (b) the flexibility of category membership, (c) the heritability of category-linked properties, and (d) within-category homogeneity. In addition to measuring essentialist beliefs, we will also examine resource allocation decisions and general social attitudes toward members of the novel group “Zarpies,” as previous work has found that exposure to generic language about novel social categories impedes children’s willingness to share resources with members of that group (Rhodes et al., 2017; Leshin et al., under review). Thus, the present study also provides an opportunity to examine the mechanisms underlying these effects.

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four experimental conditions that will vary both in the language form (generic or specific) used to describe the 16 Zarpie properties included in the storybook, as well as the causal origin (biological or social) of these properties.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Children: 
Participants will complete the study on their home or personal computers via an online platform (the Princeton & NYU Discoveries in Action Lab, or “PANDA”) developed specifically for remote developmental research. This platform captures both video and survey data from participating families. Participants on the platform are recruited in a multitude of ways, including but not limited to: community outreach events, social media advertising, posts on Prolific, and volunteer sign-ups at in-person data collection sites. For this particular study, we will only recruit participants with children between the ages of 4.5-7.99 years. Parents of eligible children will be contacted via email through their PANDA account and offered the opportunity to log on and participate. Children and parents will then follow an IRB-approved consent and assent procedure. The study will be presented as a series of short videos and verbally narrated questions, which children will respond to by clicking on the designated “buttons” to indicate their response. If children are unable to maneuver the mouse and click on the buttons themselves, parents will be encouraged to do the clicking for children (without altering their children’s responses or providing feedback in any way). At the end of the session, families will be compensated with a $10 Amazon gift card for their participation. 

Adults: 
Adult participants will be recruited from the University’s undergraduate subject pool and will complete the study via an online survey platform (no video data will be collected). All students will receive credit for participation. Adult measures and study procedures will mirror those administered to children. 

Studies should take between 10 and 15 minutes to complete.

q12.value: We selected our sample size based on a power analysis of effects obtained by Leshin et al., under review.

q13.value: We plan to stop data collection once we have obtained data from 220 participants in each sample (i.e., child and adult). We will intentionally over-sample in this way to account for drops, which occur at a rate of approximately 10% of the full sample for online data collection.

question.value:
We plan to manipulate (1) the language form of the 16 storybook prompts (generic or specific), and (2) the causal explanation used to describe the origin of the Zarpie properties in the storybook (biological or social). 

Example:
- Generic/biological: “Zarpies have stripes in their hair because Zarpies are born with stripes in their hair.”
- Generic/social: “Zarpies have stripes in their hair because Zarpies are taught to paint stripes onto their hair.”
- Specific/biological: “This Zarpies has stripes in her hair because this Zarpie was born with stripes in her hair.”
- Specific/social: “This Zarpie has stripes in her hair because this Zarpie was taught to paint stripes onto her hair”.

Full scripts are available on the OSF project page. 

Essentialism Measure #1: Category-based explanations of properties
Participants will hear three Zarpie properties from the storybook and will be asked to determine whether the property reflects features of the category (e.g., “A lot of Zarpies like to do X”) or of the individual (e.g., “This Zarpie likes to do X”). 

Essentialism Measure #2: Flexibility of category-linked properties
Participants will be told about traits or behaviors exhibited by Zarpies and will be asked whether or not they believe the Zarpie exclusively demonstrates these traits (and not others). 

Essentialism Measure #3: Heritability of category-linked properties
Participants will hear a story about a fictitious child who was born to a Zarpie mom but was raised by a non-Zarpie mom, and will be asked two manipulation check questions to ensure that they understood the story. To assess beliefs about the heritability of category-linked properties, participant’s will then be asked to make predictions about what the child will be like in the future—specifically, whether the child will possess properties of the Zarpie parent or the non-Zarpie parent. 

Essentialism Measure #4: Within-category homogeneity
Participants will be presented with information about two different properties exhibited by a Zarpie and will be asked to predict how many other members of the category “Zarpie” exhibit that same trait: (a) only one, (b) a few, (c) some, (d) most, or (e) all. Participants will receive training on how to use the visual scale to indicate their response before being asked the two target questions. 

Exploratory: Resource Allocation
Participants will be asked to allocate a finite resource (cookie or candy) to either a Zarpie or a non-Zarpie across two questions. 

Exploratory: Social Attitudes
Participants will be asked to provide their general social evaluations of two Zarpies on a 5-point scale indicating “really don’t like”, “sort of don’t like”, “not sure”, “sort of like”, or “really like”.

We intend to create a composite essentialism score using participants’ responses on our four essentialism variables: (1) category-based explanations for properties, (2) flexibility of category-linked properties, (3) heritability of category-linked properties, and (4) category homogeneity; we will examine effects of the manipulations on this composite as well as each indicator of essentialism assessed separately.

We intend to run generalized linear models from the package lme4 to examine the effects of language form and causal explanations on children’s essentialist beliefs about novel social categories, including their perceptions of (a) category-based explanations, (b) flexibility of category membership, (c) the heritability of category-linked properties. We also intend to use mixed ordinal logistic regression models from the ordinal package to assess the effects of language form and causal explanations on children’s perceptions of within-category homogeneity. 

Child Sample Only
model1c <- glmer(score_exp ~ lang_form*origin*center_age + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_child, family = binomial)
model2c <- glmer(score_flex ~ lang_form*origin*center_age + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_child, family = binomial) 
model3c <- glmer(score_sab ~ lang_form*origin*center_age + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_child, family = binomial) 
model4c <- clmm(score_hom ~ lang_form + origin + center_age + lang_form:origin + lang_form:center_age + origin:center_age + lang_form:origin:center_age +  (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_child, link = “logit”, Hess = TRUE, threshold = “flexible”)
model5c <- glmer(score ess ~ lang_form* origin*center_age + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_child, family = binomial)

Adult Sample Only
model1a <- glmer(score_exp ~ lang_form*origin + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_adult, family = binomial)
model2a <- glmer(score_flex ~ lang_form* origin + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_adult, family = binomial) 
model3a <- glmer(score_sab ~ lang_form* origin + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_adult, family = binomial) 
model4a <- clmm(score_hom ~ lang_form + origin + center_age + lang_form:origin + lang_form:center_age + origin:center_age + lang_form:origin:center_age +  (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_adult, link = “logit”, Hess = TRUE, threshold = “flexible”)
model5a <- glmer(score ess ~ lang_form* origin + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_adult, family = binomial)

Full Sample (Child + Adult)
model1f <- glmer(score_exp ~ lang_form* origin*age_group + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_all, family = binomial) 
model2f <- glmer(score_flex ~ lang_form* origin*age_group + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_all, family = binomial) 
model3f <- glmer(score_sab ~ lang_form* origin*age_group + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_all, family = binomial) 
model4f <- clmm(score_hom ~ lang_form + origin + center_age + lang_form:origin + lang_form:center_age + origin:center_age + lang_form:origin:center_age +  (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_all, link = “logit”, Hess = TRUE, threshold = “flexible”)
model5f <- glmer(score ess ~ lang_form* origin*age_group + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_all family = binomial)

Key:
*lang_form: language form (0 = specific, 1 = generic)
*origin: causal origin of the property (0 = social, 1 = biological)
*center_age: mean-centered age (Note: If there are no interactive effects, we will keep age as a covariate. If there are no mean effects of age, we will drop age from our analyses altogether.)
*age_group: age-group of sample (0 = children, 1 = adults)
*score_exp: responses to explanation items (0 = non-essentialist, 1 = essentialist)
*score_flex: responses to flexibility items (0 = non-essentialist, 1 = essentialist)
*score_sab: responses to heritability items (0 = non-essentialist, 1 = essentialist)
*score_hom: responses to the category homogeneity items (1 = only one, 2 = a few, 3 = some, 4 = most, 5 = all)
*score_ess: composite score of all (four) essentialism measures
*zarpie_explain_child = dataset including only responses from child sample
*zarpie_explain_adult = dataset including only responses from adult sample
*zarpie_explain_all = dataset including responses from full sample (child and adult)

Follow-Up Comparisons
If we find significant three-way interactions between language form, origin, and age-group on any of our dependent measures (see models 1f – 5f), we will conduct pairwise follow-up tests on the adult and child samples to determine the nature of the language*origin interaction across age-groups.
If we find significant three-way interactions between language form, origin, and mean-centered age within our child sample (see models 1c – 1f), we will dichotomize age into “old” and “young” via a median-split, and use pairwise follow-up tests to analyze the language*origin interaction for “old” and “young” children.
Based on the two sets of follow-up tests described above, we will further investigate either (a) the slow emergence of an adult-like pattern across age, or (b) the qualitatively distinct patterns across and within different age groups.  
All follow-up comparisons will be conducted using functions from the emmeans package (e.g., emmeans, emtrends).

q19.value: For the binary DVs (explanation items, flexibility items, and switched-at-birth items) we will report beta coefficients from the GLMER results, along with means that will be reported as the probability of providing an essentialist response with 95% confidence intervals, and report odds ratios as indicators of effect sizes. For our mixed-effects ordinal logistic regression analyses (homogeneity items), we will measure goodness of fit and report generalized R2, Pearson’s X2 likelihood ratios, and odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals, with higher numbers indicating broader generalization.

q20.value:
Child Sample: 
All videos of participating children will be coded to make sure a visible child is participating in order to be included in the sample. Previous work on the PANDA platform has identified extremely low rates of parent or sibling interference (less than 1% of trials), and excluding such trials had no consequence for the overall pattern of findings (Leshin et al., under review). Therefore, we will randomly select 20% of videos to be coded by a trained researcher in order to estimate the interference rate. If it is within the bounds of the interference level found in previous work, we will conclude that the interference level is negligible and highly unlikely to influence the study patterns and therefore retain all trials for analyses. However, if the interference rate in the subset of coded videos is more than the rate estimated from previous work, then we will instead code every video trial-by-trial for instances of parental interference (with 20% also checked by a reliability coder), and we will exclude any trials where the parent or a sibling interferes such that there is a question of whether the answer reflects the child’s response. If more than 25% of a child’s responses are excluded for this reason, the participant’s data will be dropped from analyses.
We do not plan to exclude based on children's success on manipulation checks and comprehension questions; however, if more than 25% of our sample fails these, we will conduct planned exploratory analyses for just the subsample who passed on the respective measures. We plan to report the percentage of participants who passed and did not pass these comprehension checks. 

Adult Sample: 
Since we will not capture video data from our adult sample, we will include additional comprehension checks at the start of our study to ensure that the paradigm is running properly (i.e., participants can hear the audio), and participants are paying attention. These will take the form of two sound checks in which participants will hear an animal sound and be asked to select which animal it belongs to. Participants who do not offer correct answers to both sound checks will be excluded from our samples. (Note: We will include these same sound checks for our child sample, too, but will not exclude based on performance.) Additionally, we will exclude adults who offer incorrect answers to more than two questions on the Winograd Schema Challenge (Levesque, Davis, & Morgenstern, 2012).

q21.value: Partial data from participants will be included if at least 50% of items are complete; participants with less than 50% completion will be excluded. We also plan to exclude any participants who are not within our age-range of 4.5-7.99 years old. For partial data that is included, we plan to just look at total essentialist responses out of total responses completed.

registration_responses.q1: Josie Benitez, Rachel Leshin, Marjorie Rhodes
registration_responses.q2:
The aim of this research is to examine the effects of linguistic form and causal explanations on essentialist beliefs, and explore how these beliefs may shift across age. Some potential data patterns and their interpretations are discussed below:
If language form matters regardless of the causal explanation provided, we should find higher endorsement of essentialism in the generic conditions than the specific conditions (across both explanation conditions). If causal explanation matters regardless of the language form used, we should find higher endorsement of essentialism in the biological origin conditions than the social origin conditions (across both linguistic form conditions). However, if linguistic form elicits essentialist beliefs only when biological explanations are provided, then we should find an interaction between linguistic form and causal explanation such that participants should exhibit higher endorsement of essentialism in the generic-biological condition than any other condition. Comparisons between a sample of children (ages 4.5-7.99) and adults will allow us to characterize how the mechanisms that elicit essentialist beliefs might shift across age. For instance, one possibility is that children exhibit stronger effects of linguistic form (with less differentiation by explanation type) and the interaction between language and explanation strengthens with age.

registration_responses.q6.question: Participants will be invited to take part in an online study to assess the effects of language and causal explanations on essentialist beliefs. Subjects will first be shown a storybook that describes 16 properties about a novel group named “Zarpies”. Using a 2x2, fully crossed between-subjects design, participants will be assigned to one of four experimental conditions. Each condition pertains to the form and content of the storybook prompts read aloud to each participant: the prompts vary both in the language form (generic vs. specific) as well as the causal origin (biological vs. social) of the observed Zarpie properties. Thus, participants will hear one of the following: (1) generic prompts paired with biological explanations, (2) generic prompts paired with social explanations, (3) specific prompts paired with biological explanations, or (4) specific prompts paired with social explanations. The storybook, read aloud only once, will be the only exposure that participants will have to the language and explanation manipulations. We will then administer a series of measures that assess distinct dimensions of participants’ essentialist beliefs about Zarpies, including perceptions of (a) category-based explanations for properties, (b) the flexibility of category membership, (c) the heritability of category-linked properties, and (d) within-category homogeneity. In addition to measuring essentialist beliefs, we will also examine resource allocation decisions and general social attitudes toward members of the novel group “Zarpies,” as previous work has found that exposure to generic language about novel social categories impedes children’s willingness to share resources with members of that group (Rhodes et al., 2017; Leshin et al., under review). Thus, the present study also provides an opportunity to examine the mechanisms underlying these effects.
registration_responses.q10.question:
Children: 
Participants will complete the study on their home or personal computers via an online platform (the Princeton & NYU Discoveries in Action Lab, or “PANDA”) developed specifically for remote developmental research. This platform captures both video and survey data from participating families. Participants on the platform are recruited in a multitude of ways, including but not limited to: community outreach events, social media advertising, posts on Prolific, and volunteer sign-ups at in-person data collection sites. For this particular study, we will only recruit participants with children between the ages of 4.5-7.99 years. Parents of eligible children will be contacted via email through their PANDA account and offered the opportunity to log on and participate. Children and parents will then follow an IRB-approved consent and assent procedure. The study will be presented as a series of short videos and verbally narrated questions, which children will respond to by clicking on the designated “buttons” to indicate their response. If children are unable to maneuver the mouse and click on the buttons themselves, parents will be encouraged to do the clicking for children (without altering their children’s responses or providing feedback in any way). At the end of the session, families will be compensated with a $10 Amazon gift card for their participation. 

Adults: 
Adult participants will be recruited from the University’s undergraduate subject pool and will complete the study via an online survey platform (no video data will be collected). All students will receive credit for participation. Adult measures and study procedures will mirror those administered to children. 

Studies should take between 10 and 15 minutes to complete.
registration_responses.q14.question:
We plan to manipulate (1) the language form of the 16 storybook prompts (generic or specific), and (2) the causal explanation used to describe the origin of the Zarpie properties in the storybook (biological or social). 

Example:
- Generic/biological: “Zarpies have stripes in their hair because Zarpies are born with stripes in their hair.”
- Generic/social: “Zarpies have stripes in their hair because Zarpies are taught to paint stripes onto their hair.”
- Specific/biological: “This Zarpies has stripes in her hair because this Zarpie was born with stripes in her hair.”
- Specific/social: “This Zarpie has stripes in her hair because this Zarpie was taught to paint stripes onto her hair”.
registration_responses.q15.question:
Full scripts are available on the OSF project page. 

Essentialism Measure #1: Category-based explanations of properties
Participants will hear three Zarpie properties from the storybook and will be asked to determine whether the property reflects features of the category (e.g., “A lot of Zarpies like to do X”) or of the individual (e.g., “This Zarpie likes to do X”). 

Essentialism Measure #2: Flexibility of category-linked properties
Participants will be told about traits or behaviors exhibited by Zarpies and will be asked whether or not they believe the Zarpie exclusively demonstrates these traits (and not others). 

Essentialism Measure #3: Heritability of category-linked properties
Participants will hear a story about a fictitious child who was born to a Zarpie mom but was raised by a non-Zarpie mom, and will be asked two manipulation check questions to ensure that they understood the story. To assess beliefs about the heritability of category-linked properties, participant’s will then be asked to make predictions about what the child will be like in the future—specifically, whether the child will possess properties of the Zarpie parent or the non-Zarpie parent. 

Essentialism Measure #4: Within-category homogeneity
Participants will be presented with information about two different properties exhibited by a Zarpie and will be asked to predict how many other members of the category “Zarpie” exhibit that same trait: (a) only one, (b) a few, (c) some, (d) most, or (e) all. Participants will receive training on how to use the visual scale to indicate their response before being asked the two target questions. 

Exploratory: Resource Allocation
Participants will be asked to allocate a finite resource (cookie or candy) to either a Zarpie or a non-Zarpie across two questions. 

Exploratory: Social Attitudes
Participants will be asked to provide their general social evaluations of two Zarpies on a 5-point scale indicating “really don’t like”, “sort of don’t like”, “not sure”, “sort of like”, or “really like”.
registration_responses.q16.question: We intend to create a composite essentialism score using participants’ responses on our four essentialism variables: (1) category-based explanations for properties, (2) flexibility of category-linked properties, (3) heritability of category-linked properties, and (4) category homogeneity; we will examine effects of the manipulations on this composite as well as each indicator of essentialism assessed separately.
registration_responses.q17.question:
We intend to run generalized linear models from the package lme4 to examine the effects of language form and causal explanations on children’s essentialist beliefs about novel social categories, including their perceptions of (a) category-based explanations, (b) flexibility of category membership, (c) the heritability of category-linked properties. We also intend to use mixed ordinal logistic regression models from the ordinal package to assess the effects of language form and causal explanations on children’s perceptions of within-category homogeneity. 

Child Sample Only
model1c <- glmer(score_exp ~ lang_form*origin*center_age + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_child, family = binomial)
model2c <- glmer(score_flex ~ lang_form*origin*center_age + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_child, family = binomial) 
model3c <- glmer(score_sab ~ lang_form*origin*center_age + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_child, family = binomial) 
model4c <- clmm(score_hom ~ lang_form + origin + center_age + lang_form:origin + lang_form:center_age + origin:center_age + lang_form:origin:center_age +  (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_child, link = “logit”, Hess = TRUE, threshold = “flexible”)
model5c <- glmer(score ess ~ lang_form* origin*center_age + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_child, family = binomial)

Adult Sample Only
model1a <- glmer(score_exp ~ lang_form*origin + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_adult, family = binomial)
model2a <- glmer(score_flex ~ lang_form* origin + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_adult, family = binomial) 
model3a <- glmer(score_sab ~ lang_form* origin + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_adult, family = binomial) 
model4a <- clmm(score_hom ~ lang_form + origin + center_age + lang_form:origin + lang_form:center_age + origin:center_age + lang_form:origin:center_age +  (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_adult, link = “logit”, Hess = TRUE, threshold = “flexible”)
model5a <- glmer(score ess ~ lang_form* origin + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_adult, family = binomial)

Full Sample (Child + Adult)
model1f <- glmer(score_exp ~ lang_form* origin*age_group + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_all, family = binomial) 
model2f <- glmer(score_flex ~ lang_form* origin*age_group + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_all, family = binomial) 
model3f <- glmer(score_sab ~ lang_form* origin*age_group + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_all, family = binomial) 
model4f <- clmm(score_hom ~ lang_form + origin + center_age + lang_form:origin + lang_form:center_age + origin:center_age + lang_form:origin:center_age +  (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_all, link = “logit”, Hess = TRUE, threshold = “flexible”)
model5f <- glmer(score ess ~ lang_form* origin*age_group + (1 | ID), data = zarpie_explain_all family = binomial)

Key:
*lang_form: language form (0 = specific, 1 = generic)
*origin: causal origin of the property (0 = social, 1 = biological)
*center_age: mean-centered age (Note: If there are no interactive effects, we will keep age as a covariate. If there are no mean effects of age, we will drop age from our analyses altogether.)
*age_group: age-group of sample (0 = children, 1 = adults)
*score_exp: responses to explanation items (0 = non-essentialist, 1 = essentialist)
*score_flex: responses to flexibility items (0 = non-essentialist, 1 = essentialist)
*score_sab: responses to heritability items (0 = non-essentialist, 1 = essentialist)
*score_hom: responses to the category homogeneity items (1 = only one, 2 = a few, 3 = some, 4 = most, 5 = all)
*score_ess: composite score of all (four) essentialism measures
*zarpie_explain_child = dataset including only responses from child sample
*zarpie_explain_adult = dataset including only responses from adult sample
*zarpie_explain_all = dataset including responses from full sample (child and adult)

Follow-Up Comparisons
If we find significant three-way interactions between language form, origin, and age-group on any of our dependent measures (see models 1f – 5f), we will conduct pairwise follow-up tests on the adult and child samples to determine the nature of the language*origin interaction across age-groups.
If we find significant three-way interactions between language form, origin, and mean-centered age within our child sample (see models 1c – 1f), we will dichotomize age into “old” and “young” via a median-split, and use pairwise follow-up tests to analyze the language*origin interaction for “old” and “young” children.
Based on the two sets of follow-up tests described above, we will further investigate either (a) the slow emergence of an adult-like pattern across age, or (b) the qualitatively distinct patterns across and within different age groups.  
All follow-up comparisons will be conducted using functions from the emmeans package (e.g., emmeans, emtrends).

attributes.title: The emotional body and time perception: A replication of Sylvie Droit-Volet (2015)
attributes.description:
The purpose of the experiment is two-fold. We are both partially replicating and modifying the experimental design from Droit-Volet & Gil (2016) who examined the effects of emotional bodily expressions, without facial cues, on perception of time using a temporal bisection task. There will be two conditions to which a participant can be randomly assigned: one with the original images, and one with reduced outlines where the salient emotional expression has been removed. 

In the first condition design, if the originally recorded effect is reliable, we expect that the durations will be perceived as longer for the fearful stimulus and that the magnitude of the lengthening effect of fearful vs sad postures will increase with the duration range. Since the paper focused on fearful responses being the salient arousing emotion that was able to impact time perception relative to the low-arousal bodily presentation of sadness, this will be the only comparison that we test. The happy/sad condition will be removed since no effect was found and we want to have the highest statistical power for looking for the main effect. This is why the first condition in the study that we are conducting is only a partial replication. 

In the second condition design, we perform the same tests but with the reduced images. We hypothesize that we will get similar effects for the high-arousal vs low-arousal images since this difference in image complexity is preserved and we find the original paper’s neuroscientific explanation to be an unlikely cause with insufficient verification. We are also working under the assumption that the arousal of the original image, on average, correlates with the complexity of the blob image. This is because the fearful bodily expressions frequently showed more animation, resulting in greater image complexity, while sad images looked more linear.

We are neglecting to include two other components from the Droit-Volet & Gil (2016): their Experiment 2 and the survey at the end of the image processing. The reason for not including their Experiment 2, showing that the effect increases with the duration, is that this component depends on the foundation of there being a reliable effect in the first place, which is the main focus of our experiment. Including it is therefore unnecessary to our primary goal, and although it might be interesting, would ultimately increase the duration of the experiment and limit the number of participants that we could pay and therefore the statistical power for the main effect. Our reasoning for not including the survey is that when using the blob-images for our second experimental condition, the goal is to prevent there from being a singular salient emotion that is perceivable in the bodily expression. By asking them about the emotion present in each image we worry that we will both increase the duration of the experiment and also weaken our own manipulation. We are therefore also removing the survey from our partial replication test of the fearful/sadness effect since we will not have a comparison. This is not a concern for us because in Droit-Volet & Gil (2016) their survey demonstrated the robustness of emotional salience resulting from their stimuli selection process, and we followed guidelines that we believe are comparable if not stricter. We also conducted a separate survey to validate the production of our blob images with 20 participants that confirmed that the process had successfully destroyed any universal emotional salience in the body expression. 

The repository used for our experiment code can be found at: https://github.com/wolstad/droit-volet-time-perception-study-replication- .

q1.value: Wesley Olstad, Connor McShaffrey, Karen Nakayama, Rebecca Peng, Dylan MacDonald, Jan Andrews, Joshua de Leeuw

q2.value:
The purpose of the following hypotheses is to express that we expect to get results that mirror and confirm those found by Droit-Volet & Gil (2015) for both image assignments, the emotional bodies and the reduced-bird-blob-images. We expect to get the same results as they did during the replication component in condition 1 under the assumption that it is a reliable effect. We expect to get a significant effect with the same experimental design in our second condition with the disrupted images because we find their explanation of the main recorded effect to be subject to the possible compound of complexity inherent to body position as opposed to emotional salience. 

Condition 1 Hypotheses:

Hypothesis1 (directional): For the 400/1600 bisection, there will be significant effects for the fear/sad group resulting in fear-classified images having a lower bisection point than sad-classified ones.


Condition 2 Hypotheses:

Hypothesis2 (directional):  For the 400/1600 bisection, there will be significant effects for the high-arousal vs low-arousal shapes with high-arousal ones having a lower bisection point than the low-arousal ones since the arousal directly correlates on average with geometric complexity.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q5.value: The participants in Group 2 will be given misleading information about what the images presented actually represent.

question.value:
Our study design is meant to recreate the study originally implemented by Sylvie Droit-Volet and Sadrine Gil and implement some modifications based on the paper “Cognition does not affect perception:Evaluating the evidence for “top-down”effects” by Chaz Firestone and Brian Scholl (2016). This is an independent measures matched pairs between-subject design.

In the first condition, a number of participants went through the temporal bisection task of 400-1600ms with fear/sadness emotion. For the emotions, images of four female actors portraying the poses associated with the said emotions were chosen from the database of the bodily expressive action stimulus test (de Gelder & Van den Stock, 2011). The faces were blurred so that the emotions were assessed solely on the poses. The two emotive poses were portrayed for the comparison durations, which were 400, 600, 800, 1000, 1200, 1400, and 1600ms. For each trial, the participant judged whether the comparison duration was short (closer to 400ms) or long (closer to 1600ms). In total, there were 14 trials (2 bodily expressions x 7 comparison durations) and 10 blocks of 14 trials for each participant. In the next part of the condition, the same procedure was conducted with a new set of participants, but with reduced images that removes human quality and emotions from the original images. The reduced images were produced by us only using images that scored 100% match of emotion identification. The images were expanded to 441x930 pixel and the same width. Major joints were outlined, from elbows to abdomen, to hips, to knees, to the lowermost side point of foot, to knee, to crotch, centre of the neck, tip of the shoulders, to outermost two tips of hands. If the fingers were fanned out, we made a block around them. The head was not outlined. Any overlaps of body parts were ignored, as well as the borders of the clothing. Natural gap was preserved. The modified images were further sized to fit in the 465x465 pixel dimensions after rotation for the experiment. The neutral stimulus dot was 400x300 pixels.

q7.value: The order of the emotions and the comparison durations presented were randomised within a trial. The 10 blocks were randomised as well. This randomization will be done by our computer program written in jsPsych.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: No data collection has been conducted for the main experiment at this time. We have already run a survey (results and BEAST images chosen are in the .csv files attached to the next question) to confirm our stimuli remove the emotional salience found in the The Bodily Expressive Action Stimulus Test (BEAST) used in the Droit-Volet study. This survey consisted of 21 participants that were exposed to our stimuli. This data has been analyzed. Due to the fact we are modifying an existing study, we do have knowledge of the original procedures, data collected, patterns discovered, and conclusions reported in the original study.

question.value: Participants will be recruited on a voluntary basis from the Prolific website. Participants will be paid for their time. Recruited participants must be female, based on the Droit-Volet study.

q11.value: The target sample size for our study is around 185 participants.

q12.value: This study is part of a research methods class, with 5 students conducting the study. question.value: The manipulated variable is the images of emotional poses, which expressed either sadness, or fear. The other manipulated variable is the reduced images that lacked in the emotions but were derived from the original images of emotional poses.

Behavioral Data Recording:
We will measure the judgements of “short” or “long” used in the temporal bisection task.

The goal of our study is to use the same analysis models as the original study. Since our stimuli reserve the complexity of the images but take out the emotional arousal, replicating the analysis plan would allow us to determine whether the effect in the original study was due to top-down effect. 

Temporal Performance Analysis:
We will use the pseudologistic model (Killeen, Fetterman, & Bizo, 1997) to derive the bisection point (BP) for individuals between experimental conditions for both parts of the study. BP is the stimulus duration for which the participants respond long as often as they respond short. A higher BP for one stimulus than another of the same duration indicates a shortened time perception. The Weber ratio will also be derived to measure time sensitivity. We will conduct a t-test on the WR for each of the two emotional groups with the two image emotional types. We will then run a t-test on the BP for each part of the study.

q19.value: We will use the standard p < 0.05 criterion for determining statistical significance for the temporal performance measures. We will use one-tailed p values in the expected direction of the hypothesis (matching the direction found in the original study).

q20.value:
Our data exclusion principle will be decided by looking at a histogram of response times. Any response times that fall far outside of the normal distribution will be subject to removal since it may indicate that the participant may not be paying attention to the task at hand. This will be the first analysis we run and we will combine the data across conditions before looking at it to assure that there is no bias. Anything removed will be noted in the write-up. 

Trials where the participant did not complete the experiment should also be excluded since this could indicate poor Wi-Fi connection, lack of interest, or a variety of other issues that would render the results invalid.

Angrilli, A.; Cherubini, P.; Pavese, A. & Manfredini, S. (1997). The influence of affective factors on time perception. Perception and Psychophysics, 59:6, 972-982. 
	In this study, Angrilli et al. used controlled, standardised photographic slides rated for emotional valence and arousal to study the effect of both affect and arousal on the perception of time. The perception of time was judged on an analog scale and reproduction of intervals by pushing a button. Heart rate and skin conductance were also monitored during stimulus presentation to measure the response arousal and attention in the participants. There was no main effect of either arousal or valence, but the interaction of both arousal and valence showed significance.
Bar-Haim, Y; Kerem, A; Lamy, D & Zakay, D (2010). When time slows down: The influence of threat on time perception in anxiety. Cognition and Emotion, 24:2, 255-263, DOI: 10.1080/02699930903387603
	In this study, Bar Haim et al. examined whether threat stimuli would cause anxious people to perceive time as moving slower, compared to non-anxious people. Their results suggest that this does occur when the stimuli are shown more quickly, but that this difference disappears when the presentation of the stimuli lasts longer.
Droit-Volet, S. & Gil, S. (2016) The emotional body and time perception, Cognition and Emotion, 30:4, 687-699, DOI: 10.1080/02699931.2015.1023180
	In this study, Droit-Volet & Gil attempt to examine the relationship between emotion and time perception, through the combined use of a temporal bisection task and images where the model’s body language conveys either happiness, sadness, or fear. They hypothesize that the emotions conveyed in the images will have a top-down effect on the perception of time (as measured by the temporal bisection task). The images used were taken from De Gelder & Van den Stock’s BEAST database. Droit-Volet & Gil find support for their hypothesis, but only with regards to fear.
De Gelder, B & Van den Stock, J. (2011) The Bodily Expressive Action Stimulus Test (BEAST): Construction and Validation of a Stimulus Basis for Measuring Perception of Whole Body Expression of Emotions. Front Psychol. 2011;2:181. doi:10.3389/fpsyg.2011.00181 
	De Gelder and Van den Stock have compiled 254 images of “whole body expressions. The faces of the models have been blurred, so that emotion is solely conveyed by body language. Furthermore, in order to confirm the categorization of the pictures, De Gelder and Van den Stock also ran surveys where participants were asked to identify the emotion present in each image. The BEAST is intended to be a resource for scientists, able to be used in a variety of different tasks and types of research. 
Firestone, C., & Scholl, B. J. (2016). Cognition does not affect perception: Evaluating the evidence for "top-down" effects. Behavioral and Brain Sciences, e229.
	In this paper, Firestone & Scholl argue that no research thus far has truly indicated the presence of top-down effects, outlining a variety of “pitfalls” that have confounded all studies on this topic. Among these is the pitfall of “low-level differences” - very basic differences between the stimuli, which could affect results but are nonetheless unaccounted for by the researchers.
Sutherland, M. R., McQuiggan, D. A., Ryan, J. D., & Mather, M. (2017). Perceptual salience does not influence emotional arousal’s impairing effects on top-down attention. Emotion, 17(4), 700-706. doi:http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/emo0000245
	Sutherland et al. investigated whether an increase in salience can modulate the top-down impairments due to arousal.

registration_responses.q6.question:
Our study design is meant to recreate the study originally implemented by Sylvie Droit-Volet and Sadrine Gil and implement some modifications based on the paper “Cognition does not affect perception:Evaluating the evidence for “top-down”effects” by Chaz Firestone and Brian Scholl (2016). This is an independent measures matched pairs between-subject design.

In the first condition, a number of participants went through the temporal bisection task of 400-1600ms with fear/sadness emotion. For the emotions, images of four female actors portraying the poses associated with the said emotions were chosen from the database of the bodily expressive action stimulus test (de Gelder & Van den Stock, 2011). The faces were blurred so that the emotions were assessed solely on the poses. The two emotive poses were portrayed for the comparison durations, which were 400, 600, 800, 1000, 1200, 1400, and 1600ms. For each trial, the participant judged whether the comparison duration was short (closer to 400ms) or long (closer to 1600ms). In total, there were 14 trials (2 bodily expressions x 7 comparison durations) and 10 blocks of 14 trials for each participant. In the next part of the condition, the same procedure was conducted with a new set of participants, but with reduced images that removes human quality and emotions from the original images. The reduced images were produced by us only using images that scored 100% match of emotion identification. The images were expanded to 441x930 pixel and the same width. Major joints were outlined, from elbows to abdomen, to hips, to knees, to the lowermost side point of foot, to knee, to crotch, centre of the neck, tip of the shoulders, to outermost two tips of hands. If the fingers were fanned out, we made a block around them. The head was not outlined. Any overlaps of body parts were ignored, as well as the borders of the clothing. Natural gap was preserved. The modified images were further sized to fit in the 465x465 pixel dimensions after rotation for the experiment. The neutral stimulus dot was 400x300 pixels.

attributes.title: Moorean and evaluative incoherencies
attributes.description:
Expressivists in metaethics maintain that moral statements do not serve to describe the world, but that their function instead is to express that the speaker is in a certain conative or affective state of mind. 

The contrast between moral and non-moral statements is sometimes presented as the idea that, whereas non-moral statements express cognitive mental states such as belief, moral statements express non-cognitive mental states, such as approval. Moreover, the latter express non-cognitive states in the same way that non-moral statements express beliefs. This is Schroeder's 'Parity Thesis':

'[M]oral sentences are related to noncognitive, desire‐like states of mind in the same way that ordinary descriptive sentences are related to ordinary beliefs—they express them. (Schroeder, 2008, p. 3). 

The Parity Thesis makes a testable prediction: if moral assertions express non-cognitive attitudes in the same way that non-moral assertions express beliefs, then whatever relations hold between non-moral assertions and belief ascriptions should hold as well between moral assertions and ascriptions of the relevant non-cognitive attitudes. In particular, just as certain combinations of non-moral assertions and belief ascriptions generate so-called Moore paradoxes (1), similar combinations of moral assertions and ascriptions of non-cognitive attitudes ought to generate analogously unacceptable constructions (2).

(1) Murder is wrong but I don’t think it is wrong.
(2) Murder is wrong but I don’t disapprove of it.

Woods (2014) claims that this is not the case: sentences like (2) are not unacceptable in the same way that Moorean paradoxes are. He argues that this constitutes a major blow to the Parity Thesis. Woods, however, bases his claim that sentences like (2) are acceptable on his intuitions. But intuitions vary, and not everyone agrees with Woods on this score. 

The purpose of our study is to empirically test the acceptability of sentences like (2), and thereby provide empirical evidence that speaks to Wood's claim, the Parity Thesis, and the connection between moral language and non-cognitive attitudes that is the focus of much contemporary literature on metaethics and philosophy of language.

In a previous study, we tested the acceptability of constructions exactly like (2) (https://osf.io/vwekq/?view_only=d5281af405f54493a67cb3c2759d76ac). In this follow-up study, we will test the acceptability of the following variant of (2): 

(2') Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but I don’t disapprove of it. 

The rationale behind this choice is the following: often, a sentence like 'murder is wrong' can have a so-called 'exocentric' interpretation, where the perspective or standards that matter for evaluating the sentence are not the speaker's, but someone else's. For example, an anthropologist commenting on the practices of a certain community could say 'murder is wrong' to describe the moral practices of that community, even if the anthropologist themself doesn't share that judgment. 

More importantly, under such exocentric use, it would make perfect sense to say something like (2): after all, if the speaker is speaking exocentrically and does not agree with the first conjunct, they could very well couple that with a denial of disapproving of murder. Thus, if a participant interprets the first conjunct of (2) exocentrically, then it should be rather easy to accept the whole construction as acceptable (perhaps the same thing applies to (1), but we are not sure about it). 

In order to control for this interpretation, and make sure that participants do not interpret a sentence like (2) exocentrically, we are adding the appositive phrase 'that's how I personally feel about it' throughout all the items.

q1.value: Andres Soria Ruiz, Nils Franzén, Mora Maldonado

q2.value:
We have two hypothesis: either sentences like (2') (henceforth 'evaluative incoherencies') are acceptable or they are not.  

To test these hypotheses, we will study the acceptability of statements constructed following this template: where x is an individual-referring term and A is a propositional attitude verb,

Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but x does not A {that murder is wrong / murder}.

We will manipulate two factors on constructions that follow this template:
(a) Attitude: A will stand for 'think' or 'disapprove of' (thus the variability between assigning a full propositional clause or just a noun)
(b) Person: x will be the speaker ('I') or a third person ('Ann')

This two-way manipulation generates the following four statement-types:

(1) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but I don't think that it is wrong.           
(= Moore paradox)
(2) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but I don’t disapprove of it.                    
(= Potential evaluative paradox)
(3) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but Ann doesn't think that it is wrong. 
(= Third-personal counterpart of (1))
(4) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but Ann doesn't disapprove of it.          
(= Third-personal counterpart of (2))

Given the type of constructions that we will test, our hypotheses can be spelled out more concretely in the following research questions:

(i) Are sentences like (1)/(2) significantly less acceptable than their third-personal counterparts (3)/(4)? In other words, is the Person factor a good predictor of acceptability of these constructions (modulo potential interactions)?

(ii) Is the difference in acceptability between sentences like (1) and (3) similar to the difference in acceptability between sentences like (2) and (4)? That is, is there an interaction between the Person and Attitude factors?

(iii) How does the acceptability of (2') differ from that of (2)?

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
We have a within-subjects design with 2 factors: Person (levels: first/third) and Attitude (levels: think/disapprove).  The combination of these two factors gives rise to four sentence configurations, repeated in (1-4) below from above:

(1) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but I don't think that it is wrong.           
(= Moore paradox)
(2) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but I don’t disapprove of it.                    
(= Potential evaluative paradox)
(3) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but Ann doesn't think that it is wrong. 
(= Third-personal counterpart of (1))
(4) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but Ann doesn't disapprove of it.          
(= Third-personal counterpart of (2))

Each participant will be shown a set of 16 sentences, and for each sentence they will be asked whether they think that the sentence makes sense or not.

The 16 sentences are generated by taking the following 4 moral sentences (5)-(8) and coupling them with attitude ascriptions in the way above-described. 

(5) Murder is wrong.
(6) Volunteering is wrong.
(7) Eating meat is wrong.
(8) What she did is wrong.

The variation in the action under evaluation (murder, volunteering, etc.) is motivated by trying to make sure that participants' personal opinions about the types of action under consideration do not interfere with their judgment about the acceptability of the relevant constructions. To this effect, we include a type of act which is generally taken to be wrong (murder), a type of act which is generally taken not to be wrong (volunteering) and a type of act whose status is currently debated (eating meat); as well as an action token (what she did) whose details are unknown to participants.
