q11.value: We aim to recruit 40 participants for this study.

q12.value: This study is a follow-up to a study for which we had 34 subjects. We aim at a slightly bigger sample size because in the previous study we found more variability than expected in Moore paradoxes (which are arguably a control condition).

question.value:
Our study will manipulate two between-subject variables with two levels each:
(a) Person: whether the person to whom an attitude is ascribed is the 1st or a 3rd person.
(b) Attitude: whether the attitude ascribed is belief or disapproval.

We will expose participants to constructions and we will ask them whether they take each construction to make sense or not.

This will give rise to a single, binary variable to be measured: whether participants find each construction sensical or not.
Participants' responses, as they are binary, will be mapped into 0 ('it doesn't make sense') or 1 ('it makes sense').

We will use logistic mixed-effects regression models to analyse the results. We will run four analyses:

1) We aim to show whether the manipulated variable 'Person' is a good predictor of the acceptability of test items. 

To show this, we will do an omnibus model that tests the effect of variable Person on the responses, together with the effect of variable Attitude and of the interaction between Person and Attitude (omnibus model: response ~ Person + Attitude + Person*Attitude). 

We aim to see whether this model is better at predicting participants' responses than an otherwise similar model that does not take into account variable Person (response ~ Attitude + Person*Attitude). This would show that there is a main effect of Person in the presence of other higher-order interactions. 

Both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure. 

2) We aim to test whether there is an interaction effect of the Person and Attitude variables.
We will compare the above-described omnibus model (response ~ Person + Attitude + Person*Attitude) with an otherwise similar model that does not take into account the interaction between Person and Attitude (response ~ Person + Attitude). 

Again, both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure. 

3) We want to test whether paradoxical sentences in the disapproval attitude are below what one would expect by chance (below 50% of approval rate). 

We will subset the data to sentences in the 'disapprove' level of the Attitude factor and evaluate the effect of the Person manipulation on the responses: Response ~ Coherence +(Coherence|subject). We will use a treatment contrast coding with baseline for first Person.

4) Finally, if there is an effect of Person for disapproval-sentences in this fourth experiment, we want to see whether this effect is stronger or not than the one in Experiment 1. We will then test for an interaction between the Person and the Experiment factors, specifically for 'disapproval' Attitude (subsetting the data). 

To show this, we will compare a model that includes the interaction of Person and Experiment (levels: Study 1 & 4) (omnibus model: response ~ Person*Experiment) to a model that does not include this interaction but just the main effects (response ~ Person+Experiment). 

Again, both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure.

q19.value:
We will use the standard alpha level of 0.05 to determine significance.  

For analyses 1), 2) and 4) we will obtain p-values from a chi-square likelihood test comparing the full model to a reduced one in which the relevant predictor (Person or Interaction depending on the case) was removed. 

For the third analysis, we will follow the standard practice for generalised linear models and obtain p-values based on asymptotic Wald tests. 

The p-value for the intercept will tell us whether or not the log odds of selecting one response over other is significantly different from 0 in the baseline condition (for the first person), i.e., that the frequency with which participants say 'makes sense'/'doesn't make sense' to first person sentences significantly different from 50%. The coefficient indicates in which direction: given the coding scheme above, positive values would indicate more 'make sense' responses and negative ones more 'doesn't make sense'

The intercepts for this model is predicted to be significant and negative: participants are expected to say 'doesn't make sense'  for First person evaluative sentences. 

The p-value for the fixed effect of Condition will reveal whether responses in the Third person condition were different from the baseline (First person). This difference is expected to be significant.

q21.value: We don't expect any missing data (forced choice task).

q22.value:
In further analyses, we might want to look at another variable:
- Object-of-evaluation effects. That is, the impact of picking out different objects of evaluation for our test items. As explained in the design plan, we will have items with different types of objects of evaluation (murder, volunteering, eating meat and what-she-did). This suggests two parameters for potential scrutiny: 
(a) participants' knowledge of the act under evaluation (i.e., murder / volunteering / eating meat vs. what-she-did); and 
(b) participants' antecedent opinions about the type of act under consideration (murder vs. volunteering vs. eating meat).

A related issue for future work—which we will not explore based on our data but which it would be good to mention here—is the possibility that Moore paradoxes constructed with moral sentences ('murder is wrong but I don't think it is wrong') may turn out to be less unacceptable than Moorean paradoxes constructed with non-moral sentences ('it's raining but I don't think that it is raining'). The reason for this is, again, the possibility of exocentric readings. However, since we will not be testing the latter type of constructions in this study, this will not concern us. 

However, if our data shows that Moorean paradoxes with moral sentences are significantly more acceptable when they don't carry the appositive 'that's how I personally feel about it' than when they do, this might suggest that perhaps we should look into the role that exocentric readings could have in the acceptability of Moore paradoxes built with moral vs. non-moral sentences, given that only the latter of those accept exocentric readings.

registration_responses.q1: Andres Soria Ruiz, Nils Franzén, Mora Maldonado
registration_responses.q2:
We have two hypothesis: either sentences like (2') (henceforth 'evaluative incoherencies') are acceptable or they are not.  

To test these hypotheses, we will study the acceptability of statements constructed following this template: where x is an individual-referring term and A is a propositional attitude verb,

Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but x does not A {that murder is wrong / murder}.

We will manipulate two factors on constructions that follow this template:
(a) Attitude: A will stand for 'think' or 'disapprove of' (thus the variability between assigning a full propositional clause or just a noun)
(b) Person: x will be the speaker ('I') or a third person ('Ann')

This two-way manipulation generates the following four statement-types:

(1) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but I don't think that it is wrong.           
(= Moore paradox)
(2) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but I don’t disapprove of it.                    
(= Potential evaluative paradox)
(3) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but Ann doesn't think that it is wrong. 
(= Third-personal counterpart of (1))
(4) Murder is wrong, that's how I personally feel about it, but Ann doesn't disapprove of it.          
(= Third-personal counterpart of (2))

Given the type of constructions that we will test, our hypotheses can be spelled out more concretely in the following research questions:

(i) Are sentences like (1)/(2) significantly less acceptable than their third-personal counterparts (3)/(4)? In other words, is the Person factor a good predictor of acceptability of these constructions (modulo potential interactions)?

(ii) Is the difference in acceptability between sentences like (1) and (3) similar to the difference in acceptability between sentences like (2) and (4)? That is, is there an interaction between the Person and Attitude factors?

(iii) How does the acceptability of (2') differ from that of (2)?
registration_responses.q3: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q4: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

attributes.title: Barriers, facilitators and clinical effects of recording outpatient consultations: A scoping review
attributes.description: The first aim of this scoping review is to synthesize existing knowledge about the barriers and facilitators patients and care providers face when deciding to make audio-recordings of clinical outpatient consultations for later reference. Secondly, we aim to synthesize existing knowledge about the clinical effects of making and sharing these audio-recorded consultations for re-consultation.

summary.value:
Preregistration of Search Protocol for Scoping Review

Project title: 		                Barriers, facilitators and clinical effects of recording outpatient 
                                                consultations: A scoping review 

Authors of this protocol: 	D. Damen, E. Krahmer, M. Antheunis, R. L. Pierce, & J. E. H. Bunt


During outpatient clinics, patients receive an abundant amount of health information that is often – due to its complicated nature or due to the patients’ condition - quickly forgotten [1 – 3]. This reduced information retention is known to affect patients’ understanding of their medical condition and their treatment. For this reason, patients often decide to record the clinical consultation for later reference, with or without the physicians’ knowing or approval [4]. Previous literature reviews identified the healthcare related benefits of recording doctor-patient consultations, as well as the possible barriers and facilitators of implementing the practice [5,6,7]. These reviews, however, focused either solely on consultation recordings in oncology [5], or they did not address the barriers and facilitators clinicians face when deciding to make and share the recordings with their patients [6]. Furthermore, the most recent review restricted their search to specific study interventions, and they did not provide in-depth information about the type and format of the consultations and applications used to make and share the recordings, nor about the applicable laws that affected patients’ and clinicians’ concerns and decisions [7]. The central aim of this scoping review is to provide this in-depth information in two subsequent steps, without restricting the literature search to specific study interventions. 

The first aim of this scoping review is to synthesize existing knowledge about the barriers and facilitators patients and care providers face when deciding to make audio-recordings of clinical outpatient consultations for later reference. Secondly, we aim to synthesize existing knowledge about the clinical effects of making and sharing these audio-recorded consultations for later reference. Questions guiding this review are: What are patients’ and care providers’ needs, perceptions, and concerns about audio-recording outpatient clinics? Which patient and care characteristics determine whether a recording is likely to be made? Who is most likely to make the recording, and who is most likely to be the legal owner of these records? What are the effects of sharing audio-recorded consultations on the quality and safety of patient care, including patient and care provider decision making, their relationship, their satisfaction with the care being delivered, and the cost-effectiveness? Which legal and ethical considerations and technological aspects appear to impact these decisions and consequences?


Search strategy and eligibility criteria 

This scoping review will be conducted in accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-analyses extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR) [8]. Our search strategy will target words for recordings (i.e., audio, video, tape, digital) and consultations (e.g., office visits, outpatient clinics, medical consultations), combined with terms that are related to either patients’ and care providers’ attitudes (e.g., patient satisfaction, patient attitude, attitude of health personal), decision making processes (e.g., choice behavior, patient participation, shared decision making), or health care outcomes (e.g., quality of life, quality of healthcare).

In April 2020, we will search the following databases: Medline, EMBASE, CINAHL, PsycINFO, Cochrane Library, Web of Science, and Grey Literature databases identified through Grey Matters. We will also hand search the reference list of all primary and review articles. We will exclude literature reviews, but we will include practice briefs, fact sheets, white papers, and peer-reviewed publications (including conference proceedings) focusing on any type of population or study design (e.g., qualitative, quantitative, mix-method studies). We will search for articles from inception till 2020, with no language restrictions. 

To be included in the review, papers need to focus on patients’ and care providers’ considerations towards taping clinical consultations for later reference. Papers should either specify patients’- or care providers’ perceptions and attitudes towards making these recordings, or focus on the perceived or examined benefits or costs related to the making and sharing of these recordings with patients and clinicians. Table 1 (see supplemental file) provides an overview of the checklist for full articles.


Data extraction

The retrieved articles will be imported into Mendeley, and the first author (DD) will use this software to screen the articles and to select eligible papers based on their titles and abstracts. After this initial screening, the fifth author (JEHB) will screen a subset (10%) of the papers that were judged by the first author. This subset will contain a mix of excluded and included papers. Disagreements between the first and the fifth author will be resolved by inviting a third reviewer (EK/MA/RLP) to discuss the problematic cases. We will commence with the second round of screening when the inter-rater agreement (kappa) between the first and the fifth author is at least moderate (min.60; [9]). In the second round of screening, the first and fifth author will evaluate the selected articles from the first round based on the eligibility criteria. Again, disagreements will be resolved in discussion with a third review. Table 2 (see supplemental file) provides an overview of the data extraction items. 

References

[1] Kessels, R. P. (2003). Patients’ memory for medical information. Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine, 96(5), 219-222.

[2] Mazzi, M. A., Rimondini, M., Deveugele, M., Zimmermann, C., Moretti, F., Van Vliet, L., ... & Bensing, J. (2015). What do people appreciate in physicians' communication? An international study with focus groups using videotaped medical consultations. Health Expectations, 18(5), 1215-1226.

[3] Laws, M. B., Lee, Y., Taubin, T., Rogers, W. H., & Wilson, I. B. (2018). Factors associated with patient recall of key information in ambulatory specialty care visits: Results of an innovative methodology. PloS One, 13(2), e0191940.

[4] Barr, P. J., Bonasia, K., Verma, K., Dannenberg, M. D., Yi, C., Andrews, E., ... & Durand, M. A. (2018). Audio-/Videorecording clinic visits for patient’s personal use in the United States: Cross-sectional survey. Journal of Medical Internet Research, 20(9), e11308.

[5] Scott, J. T., Entwistle, V. A., Sowden, A. J., & Watt, I. (2001). Recordings or summaries of consultations for people with cancer. Nursing Times, 97(30), 162-169.

[6] Tsulukidze, M., Durand, M. A., Barr, P. J., Mead, T., & Elwyn, G. (2014). Providing recording of clinical consultation to patients - A highly valued but underutilized intervention: A scoping review. Patient Education and Counseling, 95(3), 297–304. 

[7] Rieger, K. L., Hack, T. F., Beaver, K., & Schofield, P. (2018). Should consultation recording use be a practice standard? A systematic review of the effectiveness and implementation of consultation recordings. Psycho-Oncology, 27(4), 1121–1128. 

[8] Tricco, A. C., Lillie, E., Zarin, W., O’Brien, K. K., Colquhoun, H., Levac, D., … Straus, S. E. (2018). PRISMA extension for scoping reviews (PRISMA-ScR): Checklist and explanation. Annals of Internal Medicine, 169(7), 467–473. 

[9] ] McHugh, M. L. (2012). Interrater reliability: the kappa statistic. Biochemia Medica, 22(3), 276–82.
